Title:
Endo-rhamnogalacturonase associated with the in planta growth
of Heterobasidion irregulare
Keywords:
Endo-rhamnogalacturonase, Heterobasidion irregulare,
fungi, necrotroph, in planta growth
Abstract:
Heterobasidion irregulare is one of five Heterobasidion
annosum sensu lato (s.l.) species, a destructive pathogen in boreal and
temperate forests of the northern hemisphere that causes root and butt
rot in conifer. A gene encoding endo-rhamnogalacturonase (HIRHG), which
belongs to the glucose hydrolase family 28 (GH28), was found in a
quantitative trait loci (QTL) region for virulence in Heterobasidion. In
this study, we showed that HIRHG was highly up-regulated during
infection of spruce bark compared with when grown in liquid culture and
that the protein was mainly produced during growth on complex carbon
sources. Furthermore, our study of endo-rhamnogalacturonase revealed
that the gene had been lost in most of the biotrophic and hemibiotrophic
plant pathogens investigated but was common in necrotrophic pathogens.
Expression of the HIRHG gene in the hemibiotrophic fungus Magnaporthe
oryzae increased its capacity to grow on pectin; however, the
transformed M. oryzae isolates did not show a significant change in
virulence in our experimental set up.
